question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Solve
\[\frac{x(x + 1)^2}{x - 7} \le 0.\]Enter your answer using interval notation.
inference:
Solution:
We have

$$\frac{x(x + 1)^2}{x - 7} \le 0$$

$$\Rightarrow \qquad x(x + 1)^2 \le 0$$

$$\Rightarrow \qquad x \le 0 \qquad \text{or} \qquad (x + 1)^2 \le 0$$

$$\Rightarrow \qquad x \le 0 \qquad \text{or} \qquad x \le -1$$

$$\Rightarrow \qquad x \le -1$$

$$\Rightarrow \qquad (-\infty, -1].$$

Final Answer: $\boxed{(-\infty, -1]}.$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
Note that $(x + 1)^2 \ge 0$ for all $x.$  For the remaining part of the expression, we can build a sign chart.

\[
\begin{array}{c|ccc}
& x < 0 & 0 < x < 7 & 7 < x \\ \hline
x & - & + & + \\
x - 7 & - & - & + \\
\frac{x(x + 1)^2}{x - 7} & + & - & +
\end{array}
\]Also, $\frac{x(x + 1)^2}{x - 7} = 0$ at $x = 0$ and $x = -1.$  Thus, the solution is $x \in \boxed{\{-1\} \cup [0,7)}.$
